qas.question: Which U.S. government agency keeps a large amount of information on genomes?
What is a mammal whose genome has been sequenced?
What is a fish whose genome has been sequenced?
When was the Neanderthal's genome sequenced?
How old in years was the material that was used to sequence the Neanderthal genome?
What has extracting genes from a Neanderthal made it easier for scientists to do?
What is happening with the knowledge gained from sequencing a mouse?

plausible_answers.text: one of several comprehensive databases of genomic information

qas.question: What have scientists been maintaining since 2013?
Where has the bacteria E. coli been found to be sequenced?
How old was the material used to sequence the Arabidopsis thaliana genome?

context: The development of new technologies has made it dramatically easier and cheaper to do <b5_0>sequencing<b5_0/>, and the number of complete genome sequences is <b6_0>growing rapidly<b6_0/>. The <a0_0>US National Institutes of Health<a0_0/> maintains <b7_0>one of several comprehensive databases of genomic information<b7_0/>. Among the thousands of completed genome sequencing projects include those for rice, a <a1_0>mouse<a1_0/>, the plant Arabidopsis thaliana, the <a2_0>puffer fish<a2_0/>, and the bacteria E. coli. In <a3_0>December 2013<a3_0/>, scientists first sequenced the entire genome of a Neanderthal, an extinct species of humans. The genome was extracted from the toe bone of a <a4_0><b9_0>130,000<a4_0/>-year-old<b9_0/> Neanderthal found <b8_0>in a Siberian cave<b8_0/>.
